What if we could rebuild a 3D graphics engineâ€¦ from scratch, in JavaScript? Thatâ€™s the ambitious challenge we tackled as a team of two during our second-year Scientific Project at INSA Toulouse. Between math, geometry, debugging chaos, and final pride, hereâ€™s a glimpse of real-intgine, our tongue-in-cheek nod to Unreal Engine â€” but minimal and homebrewed in JS.


Why JavaScript?


We were advised to use Python â€” itâ€™s accessible, rich in libraries, and beginner-friendly. But we wanted something different. After briefly trying C++ and facing its complexity, JavaScript stood out: it runs in the browser, doesnâ€™t require installation, and lets us draw directly using an HTML5 canvas.


How the graphics engine works


A 3D engine transforms 3D object data into a 2D projection, based on a virtual cameraâ€™s viewpoint. Sounds simpleâ€¦ until you try coding it. We needed to dive into 3D math, projection geometry, and frame-by-frame rendering.

1. Modeling the camera and the screen

The cameraâ€™s position and orientation determine where the virtual screen (projection plane) is placed. Using trigonometry and a field of view (fov) parameter, we dynamically calculate this screen on each frame.

2. Transforming the points

Each 3D vertex is first translated relative to the camera, then rotated around X and Z axes (Euler angles) to simulate the cameraâ€™s orientation in space.

3. Perspective projection

We apply a perspective projection â€” which flattens 3D space while preserving depth â€” to make distant objects look smaller and closer ones larger, giving a realistic visual depth.

4. Face sorting

Each triangle (face) must be drawn in the correct order to avoid visual glitches. We sort faces based on the distance between their center and the camera, ensuring that farther faces are drawn first.


Limitations (and what we learned)


  • ğŸ›‘ No lighting, no textures, no Z-buffer. We used the simple fill() method to color faces, which can result in inaccuracies and hidden face issues.
  • ğŸ•³ï¸ Our face-sorting method is based on center distance, which breaks when faces are large or oddly shaped.
  • ğŸ§  But we now understand how 3D rendering truly works: rotations, projections, rendering loops â€” itâ€™s no longer a black box.

Conclusion


Building a tiny 3D engine in JavaScript is totally doable â€” and incredibly educational. With real-intgine, weâ€™re not playing photorealistic games (yet), but weâ€™ve built a real-time, functional engine from first principles.

Weâ€™re proud of what we achieved. And who knows? Maybe a future version will include lighting, shadows, or even WebGL acceleration.
